Foster a a Novartis Institute for BioMedical Research Vienna, Austria; b Hertie Institute for Clinical Brain Research, Tübingen, GermanyFTY720 is a sphingosine-1 phosphate receptor agonist which causes a reversible redistribution of lymphocytes from the circulation to peripheral lymph nodes. It is efficacious in experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) induced with central nervous system (CNS) tissue. A multicenter, double-blind study with FTY720 as oral monotherapy is underway in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients. Since visual and somatosensory-evoked potentials (VEP, SEP) are diagnostic indicators for MS, our aim was to record these responses in myelin-oligodendrocyte-glycoprotein (MOG)-induced EAE in DA rats, a stringent model where demyelination and axonal loss resemble MS lesions. Rats received FTY720 (0.5 mg/kg) or vehicle for 3 weeks, starting on day 0. Changes in VEP and SEP latencies positively correlated with EAE onset and high disease severity around day 10 in vehicle-treated controls. A similar relationship was observed with the SEP amplitude, while reduction of VEP amplitude only appeared by day 30. FTY720 significantly protected against clinical symptoms and prevented latency delays, amplitude reductions during treatment. Our data suggest that different pathomechanistic entities may distinguish initial clinical signs linked to CNS lesion development (i.e., conduction block due to edema) from later symptoms (i.e., axonal loss). This approach using electrophysiological parameters could enhance the preclinical predictability for investigational drugs like FTY720 in MS, especially in high-risk patients with early visual acuity symptoms.271The role of a protease inhibitor in suppression of EAE F. Mokhtarian, G. Hassen, L. Kessner and A. Stracher State University of New York, Brooklyn, NY, USA EAE has been used as an animal model to study the pathogenesis of and treatment options for MS. Proteolytic enzymes from activated microglia and macrophages (Ma) play an important role in the pathology of MS. Here, we have determined the effect of the inhibition of calpain (proteolytic enzyme), in suppressing EAE, and to study the immunological mechanisms that operate during this inhibition. EAE was induced in C57BL/6 mice, by immunization with MOG 35-55. Calpain Inhibitor (CI) was administered daily at different time points following immunization. Treatment with CI showed improvement of the clinical and histological signs of EAE, when applied early after immunization. The fluorogenic assay showed higher proteolytic activity of calpain in the tissues of untreated EAE mice compared with the treated animals. Similarly, immunofluorescent staining and confocal microscopy showed more intense staining for CD45, CD11b and calpain, in the spinal cords of mice with EAE than in those of other groups, and localized calpain, in microglia and Ma. This study may lead to the finding of a calpain inhibitor as a therapeutic measure for inflammatory demyelinating diseases such as MS. Zamvil b a Stanford University, Stanford, USA; b University of California, San Francisco, CA, USA We showed that atorvastatin promotes a Th2 bias and reverses chronic and relapsing paralysis in EAE. Atorvastatin inhibited IFN-gamma inducible expression of MHC II and costimulatory properties. As STAT1activation is required for IFN-gamma inducible expression of these molecules, we examined whether atorvastatin inhibited IFN-gamma inducible STAT1 activation. Protection from relapsing-remitting EAE was sustained after oral atorvastatin was discontinued, suggesting that atorvastatin-induced Th2 cells could mediate bystander suppression. Thus, we examined whether these regulatory Th2 cells protect mice from EAE in an epitope-specific manner or if they could mediate bystander suppression. Both IFN-gammainducible STAT1 and class I expression was inhibited on APC by atorvastatin and reversed by l-mevalonate. Atorvastatin-induced PLP-p139-151-specific Th2 cells protected mice from EAE induced by PLP p139-151 or PLP p178-191. Conversely, atorvastatin-induced PLP p178-191-specific Th2 cells protected mice from EAE induced by either peptide. Atorvastatin-induced Th2 cells are capable of mediating bystander suppression. In addition to inhibition of MHC II upregulation, atorvastatin also inhibits IFN-gamma inducible MHC I expression suggesting potential regulation on other T cell subsets. Steinman b a Bayhill Therapeutics Inc., Palo Alto, CA, USA; b Stanford University, Stanford, CA, USAObjective: To develop a novel treatment for multiple sclerosis (MS) using a DNA vaccine in combination with atorvastatin. Background: We have previously shown that tolerizing DNA vaccines encoding autoantigens specifically turn off pathogenic autoimmune responses. We have built on these results by exploring the efficacy of a combination therapy involving DNA vaccines and atorvastatin. Methods: We use the experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE) model to administer the DNA vaccine encoding the self-antigen proteolipid protein (PLP) intramuscularly along with atorvastatin orally. The animals are evaluated both for clinical and immune parameters of disease severity. Results: We demonstrate that this combination therapy is able to reverse several parameters of EAE severity in already established disease, including reduced mean disease severity as well as an increase in the number of disease-free days. Furthermore, the combination therapy reduces the number of interferongamma producing antigen-specific T cells in the treated mice. Conclusions: Our results demonstrate that a combination of antigen-specific DNA vaccine with atorvastatin is an effective therapy for MS as shown by disease reversal in the EAE model and by antigen-specific reduction in the number of interferon-gamma producing cells. Based on these results, we are in clinical development of a similar antigen-specific DNA vaccine and atorvastatin combination therapy for MS (designated BHT-3009) that is scheduled to enter into phase I clinical trials in mid-2004.275Therapeutic effects of peroxynitrite decomposition catalysts in experimental allergic encephalomyelitis G.S. Scott, R.J. Flower, C. Bolton William Harvey Research Institute, London, UK Several reports have proposed that peroxynitrite is involved in the pathogenesis of multiple sclerosis (MS) and experimental allergic encephalomyelitis (EAE). There is evidence of increased peroxynitrite production in central nervous system tissues from MS patients and animals with EAE. Furthermore, treatment with uric acid, an inhibitor of peroxynitrite-mediated reactions, protects against EAE. Novel compounds have been developed that catalytically isomerise peroxynitrite and decompose the reactive molecule to inactive nitrate. The present study examines the therapeutic effects of the peroxynitrite decomposition catalyst, 5,10,15,20-tetrakis(4-sulfonatophenyl)porphyrinato iron (III), chloride (FeTPPS) in EAE. Male Biozzi AB/H mice, immunised to induce a relapsing and remitting form of EAE, received twice daily intraperitoneal injections of FeTPPS (20 mg/kg body weight), therapeutically for 5 days prior to the onset of acute or relapse symptoms. Control animals received saline vehicle. Signs of EAE were scored using a 7-point severity scale. All saline-treated mice exhibited disease signs, together with a high incidence of paralysis. In contrast, the severity of acute and relapse symptoms was significantly reduced in animals therapeutically dosed with FeTPPS. Our finding that FeTPPS exerts protective effects in EAE further supports the theory that peroxynitrite is a primary candidate in disease development. In addition, the implication of a role for peroxynitrite in the pathogenesis of MS indicates that FeTPPS and other peroxynitrite decomposition catalysts may be useful therapeutic agents.

back_matter.text: Cervical lymph nodes (CLN) have a crucial role in immune regulation and have been described to act as the first lymphoid draining site of the brain. Previously, myelin antigens were demonstrated in autopsy material of multiple sclerosis (MS) patients at an advanced disease stage. In this pilot study, we aimed to determine whether myelin antigens could be detected in the CLN of MS patients. We tested if ultrasound guided fine needle aspiration cytology (USgFNAC) is a suitable method to obtain cells, in vivo, from non-enlarged cervical lymph nodes (CLN) of MS patients, and whether myelin proteins could be detected in these CLN. Cell aspiration was performed in MS patients and healthy controls. Macrophages containing myelin basic protein (MBP) and proteolipid protein (PLP) were found in CLN of all MS patients, whereas these could be detected in only a minority of the healthy controls. This novel approach allows investigation of the first draining site of the brain for in vivo analysis of the immune regulation of MS.

Impaired suppressive capacity and reduced FOXP3 expression of CD4+CD25+ regulatory T cells isolated from multiple sclerosis patients K. Venken, N. Hellings, J. Schuermans, J. Raus and P. Stinissen Biomedisch Onderzoeksinstituut, Limburgs Universitair Centrum, Diepenbeek, BelgiumAccumulating evidence indicates an active role for CD4+CD25+ regulatory T cells (Tregs) in the prevention of autoimmune diseases. We studied the phenotypic and functional characteristics of Tregs isolated from the peripheral blood of patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) and age-matched healthy controls (HC). Immunomagnetically isolated CD25+ (Tregs) and CD25À (responders) CD4+ T cells were studied for their phenotypic expression by flow cytometry and for FOXP3 expression by quantitative real-time PCR. The suppressive capacity of Tregs was analysed using a coculture assay. Treg cells from MS patients and HC were CD45RO+/CD45RAÀ and had an increased expression of HLA-DR, CD54, CD95, GITR and intracellular CTLA-4 as compared to their CD4+CD25À counterparts. Tregs of HC (n=14) were anergic and significantly suppressed the proliferation and cytokine production (IFNgamma) of anti-CD3 stimulated responders in a cell-contact dependent manner. Interestingly, the mean suppressive capacity and relative FOXP3 expression of Tregs was significantly lower in RR-MS (n=15) as compared to CP-MS (n=6) and HC. Tregs from most RR-MS patients (11/15) were not anergic. Our data suggest that Tregs have a suboptimal in vitro suppressive capacity in RR-MS which could reflect an impairment of Treg function in RR-MS patients.

Identification and functional characterization of HLA-G expressing T cells, a subset with putative regulatory properties and preferential accumulation in the cerebrospinal fluid: implications for immune surveillance mechanisms and autoimmunity in the CNS U. Feger a , B. Schreiner a , D. Wernet b , J. Dichgans a , A. Melms a and H. Wiendl a a Department of Neurology, University of Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany; b Department of Transfusion Medicine, University of Tübingen, Tübingen, Germany HLA-G is a nonclassical HLA-class-I antigen with highly limited tissue distribution under physiological conditions and chiefly attributed negative immune regulatory functions. We identified, isolated and functionally characterized a subpopulation of CD4 and CD8T-cells constitutively expressing the immunotolerizing molecule HLA-G. Whereas under physiological conditions, HLA-G expressing T cells in the periphery are either undetectable or present at very low percentages (median 0.6% of CD4 and 2.5% of CD8 T cells), these subsets were elevated in the CSF: HLA-G T-cells were found in subjects without CNS pathology but were especially high in patients with chronic neuroinflammatory disorders such as MS (median 10.8% of CD4 and 7.6% of CD8 T cells, n=15). CD4 HLA-G cells are mainly CD45RA(+) but are negative or low for CD28. CCR7-coexpression suggests a migratory phenotype that allows homing into the CNS compartment. Purified HLA-G T-cells, isolated by a multistep MACS separation procedure, constitutively express IL-10, IL-6 and IL-1beta. Importantly, CD4 HLA-G T cells have low proliferative capacity under primary stimulatory conditions. HLA-G expressing T cells were identified as a specialized T-cell subset with putative regulatory properties. Preferential accumulation in the CNS and elevation in MS suggests that these cells have important functions in CNS immune surveillance and regulation of neuroinflammation.

Expression of ionotropic glutamate GluR3 receptors on T lymphocytes of multiple sclerosis (MS) patients and glutamate effects on antigen specific T-cell proliferation and chemotactic response P. Sarchielli, L. Greco, A. Candeliere, Ar. Floridi, Al. Floridi and G. Capocchi University of Perugia, Perugia, Italy Aims: We investigated the expression of GluR3 on T cells of relapsingremitting MS patients by RT-PCR and Western blot. T-cell proliferation to MBP and MOG and CXCR1, CXCR3, CXCR4 and CXCR5-mediated Tcell chemotactic migration was also assessed both in the presence and absence of glutamate. Results: An up-regulation of GluR3 receptors was demonstrated on peripheral T cells of MS patients, particularly in those assessed during a relapse. Proliferation of total T-lymphocyte and CD+ T cells to MBP and MOG was increased by glutamate (10 nM) in MS patients and at lower extent in controls. Glutamate (10 nM), induced an increase in the CXCR3, CXCR4 and CXCR5-mediated T-cell chemotactic migration toward the key chemokines RANTES, CXCL12/stromal cell-derived factor-1 and MIP-1a, more accentuated in MS patients. Chemotactic migration in MS patients was more accentuated during relapses. Discussion: The abnormal GluR3 expression on T cells of MS patients suggests the involvement of glutamate-mediated mechanisms in the T-cell function, particularly during the active stages of the disease. Involvement of glutamate in favouring T-cell transmigration to the CNS could explain increased chemotactic response to RANTES and MIP-1alpha chemokines which have been shown to play a significant role in T-cell homing to demyelinating lesions. Background: So far all attempts to reproduce CNS pathology using onconeuronal antigens have failed. Here, we report a first animal model based on T cell transfer of CD4+ T cells specific for autologous onconeuronal antigens in the rat. Methods: Sequence of rat Pnma1, Yo (cdr2) and HuD were determined by RT-PCR, cloned into the expression vector pQE60 and recombinant protein was purified using metal chelate chromatography. Rats were immunized with these proteins and antigen specific CD4+ TH1 T cell lines were generated from draining lymph nodes 10 days p.i. Freshly activated T cell blasts were transferred into naive rats, which were sacrificed 6 days later. Results: Proliferation assays demonstrated that the CD4+ TH1 T cells were highly specific for their cognate antigen. Transfer of T cells specific for rat-Yo and rat-Pnma1 in DA, but not Lewis rat, induced a subclinical perivascular and parenchymal inflammatory response. In Yo, encephalitis focussed predominantly in the cerebellum, and in Pnma1 in the mesencephalon, both areas mainly involved in human disease. Inflammation was CNS specific and not found in other tissues. Conclusion: The inflammatory response in the CNS following the adoptive transfer of T cells specific for autologous onconeuronal antigens to DA rats causes an encephalitis differentially affecting areas involved in the corresponding human disease. This strongly supports the hypothesis that the pathogenesis of paraneoplastic neurological syndromes in man involves an autoimmune T cell component.The role of group A beta hemolytic streptococcus infections in the development of tic disorders (TD) and obsessive compulsive disorders (OCD) as environmental factors is controversial. According to this hypothesis, during the infection formation of autoantibodies in the child lead to an autoimmune disorder, which in turn results in movement disorders, TD and/or OCD. In order to test this hypothesis we searched for anti-neuronal antibodies, and measured C-Reactive Protein (CRP) levels in children and adolescents diagnosed with TD and OCD. Children and adolescents who were referred to Istanbul University, Istanbul Medical Faculty, Department of Child Psychiatry and diagnosed with either TD and/ or OCD according to DSM-IV criteria (n=28) were compared with a healthy control group (n=15) having similar age and gender characteristics. Regardless of streptococcus infection history the sera of all cases and control group underwent a search for antinuclear, cytoskeletal, and antineuronal antibodies using the indirect immunflourescence technique. Immunonefelometry technique was used to determine the CRP levels. The comparison of positive and negative results regarding the antineuronal antibodies and CRP levels did not yield a statistically significant difference between the TD/OCD group and normal controls. The results suggest two possibilities: either such antibodies may not be involved in the pathogenesis of TD/OCD, or our method may not be sensitive enough to detect those antibodies.

Characterization of glutamic acid decarboxylase antibodies T. Chang and A. Vincent Oxford University, Oxford, UK Anti-GAD antibodies (GADAb) are detected at high titres in 60% of patients with stiff person syndrome, and some patients with cerebellar ataxia and other neurological disorders such as myoclonic epilepsy. The role of GADAb in the pathogenesis of neurological disease still remains elusive and it is not clear whether the antibodies are potentially pathogenic, or whether they arise secondary to neuronal damage. Here we report the preliminary characterisation of GAD Abs. Fifteen sera of patients with neurological disease, sent for routine analysis, were studied. We used a commercial preparation of 125I-GAD (specific activity 1755 cpm/fmol; RSR, Cardiff) and antisera to human IgG and IgG subclasses. GADAb levels ranged from 180 to 80 000 U/ml. 10 sera had titres over 1000 U/ml. The K d values in seven sera varied between 0.009 and 0.74 nM and the titres based on the Bmax ranged from 0.67 to 6500 nM. IgG1 was the predominant subclass in 4 samples with high GADAb (N30 000 U/ml) ranging from 57.3% to 73.2% of the total. These results show that GADAbs are mainly IgG1 subclass and very high affinity, similar to those of other well defined autoantigens, eg. the acetylcholine receptor. These results suggest the need to consider carefully the pathogenic role of this very highly specific antibody.Paraneoplastic neurological syndromes are tumour-associated diseases of the nervous system. Since autoantibodies against different onconeural antigens have been found, an autoimmune etiology is suspected. We identified synaptophysin as a new autoantigen in a patient with paraneoplastic sensomotoric and autonomic neuropathy and small cell lung cancer. In indirect immunofluorescence test, the patients serum showed binding in the cerebellum and in myenteric plexus of the gut. The binding pattern was predominnatly synaptic. Immunoblotting and 2D-gelelectrophoresis identified synaptophysin, a 38-kDa synaptic protein as the underlying autoantigen. No other autoantibodies were detectable in the patients serum. Synaptophysin was not only expressed in cerebellar tissue and myenteric plexus, but also in small cell lung cancer (SCLC) cell lines. In patients with non-paraneoplastic neuropathies or healthy controls, the autoantibody was not detectable. In 20 SCLC patients without neurological syndromes, two patients had low-titer anti-synaptophysin reactivity. We conclude, that synaptophysin is another autoantigen in paraneoplastic neurological syndromes.

Anti-neuronal antibodies in paraneoplastic encephalitis K. Tanaka a , M. Nishizawa a , M. Tanaka b and M. Motomura c a Niigata University, Niigata, Japan; b National West Niigata Central Hospital, Niigata, Japan; c Nagasaki University Hospital, Nagasaki, JapanThe antineuronal autoantibodies detected in patients with paraneoplastic neurological syndrome (PNS) will be the good markers for the diagnosis of this group of disorders. We examined the frequency of PNS-related autoantibodies in the sera of patients with suspected paraneoplastic encephalitis (PE). Materials and methods: We examined 93 sera from patients with suspected PE (male/female 59:34, ages 59.9F12.4) for antibodies against Yo, Hu, Ri, Ma-2, CRMP-5 and amphipysin with Western blot or ELISA using each of the antigen-specific fusion proteins. Anti-VGCC and anti-VGKC antibodies were examined with immunoprecipitation methods using 125I labeled MVIIC and alpha-dendrotox extracted from digitoxin treated rat cerebellum as the antigens respectively. Results: PNS-related antibodies were positive in 16 sera, including 6 Hu-positve (anti-VGCC antibody was found in one of six sera), 1 amphiphysin (+), 1 CRMP-5 (+), 3 VGKC (+) and 5 VGCC (+). Discussion: 17% of patients suspected as PE showing subacutely deteriorated mental disorder, convulsion or consciousness disturbance without any known cause but cancer-related (small cell lung cancer, nonsmall cell lung cancer, ovary cancer, etc.) possessed PNS-related antibodies. Neurological symptoms of those with anti-VGCC or anti-VGKC antibodies improved favorably after the treatment of cancer, while those with other antibodies against intracellular antigens did not. The antibodies against channel proteins might be the predictive factor for better neurological prognosis in PNS. The use of protein biochips to characterize specific molecular interactions for clinical diagnosis is currently expanding. Among the possible detection methods, surface plasmon resonance (SPR) allows real-time monitoring of the binding of an injected analyte to a ligand coupled to a sensor chip. We have established methods by which synaptic vesicles containing potential auto-antigens can be immobilized. The possible use of other types of organelles and membrane preparations containing autoantibody targets is being evaluated. Subcellular fractions can be anchored on chips by protein or lipid interactions; in this way putative auto-antigens associated with membranes are presented in their native environment. This procedure can provide a protein chip appropriate for screening for autoimmune responses. SPR analysis has many advantages compared to routine methods, including automatic operation, speed (10-15 min/sample), sensitivity, specificity and reproducibility. We are currently performing a clinical study to evaluate global anti-neural autoantibody levels in sera from patients with lung cancer but with no neurological symptoms. Future projects will include analysis of autoimmune responses in patients with classicals paraneoplastic neurological syndromes.

Characterization of paraneoplastic neurologic syndromes in 111 patients using PNSEURONETWORK guidelines L. Lorusso a , I.K. Hart b , B. Giometto c , R. Pezzani d , D. Ferrari a , G. Ngonga a , G. Ricevuti e , E. Marshall f and J. Broome g a M. Mellini Hospital, Chiari, Italy; b University of Liverpool, Liverpool, UK; c Ca' Foncello Hospital, Treviso, Italy; d University of Padua, Padua, Italy; e University of Pavia, Pavia, Italy; f Oncology Centre, Clatterbridge, UK; g The Walton Centre for Neurology and Neurosurgery, Liverpool, UK PNS are rare, but often associated with particular tumours and onconeural antibodies. The PNSEURONETWORK has recently proposed guidelines to aid their diagnosis. To apply the new guidelines for definite or possible PNS to 111 patients. 51 were definite PNS: 20 had cerebellar degeneration, 16 encephalomyelitis, 6 polyneuropathy, 2 retinal degeneration, 2 polyneur-opathy+encephalomyelitis, and 1 each had motor neurone disease, limbic encephalitis, stiff-man syndrome, or multiple mononeuropathy. 44 had an associated tumour: 20 lung, 5 ovary, 5 prostate, and 4 breast. Lymphoma, gastric or colon tumour were each found in 2 patients. Mesothelioma or uterus, kidney, or liver tumours were each found in 1 patient. The antibodies found were 15 Hu, 10 Yo, 2 partially characterised, 1Tr, and 1 amphyphisin. 60 were possible PNS: 30 had polyneuropathy, 14 cerebellar degeneration, 5 encephalomyelitis, 5 sensory polyneuropathy, and 2 opsoclonus. Polyneuropathy+encephalitis, polyneuropathy+necrotizing myelitis, myopathy, and neuromyotonia were each found in 1 patient. Twenty-one patients had a tumour: 9 lung, 6 prostate, 2 lymphoma, 2 breast, 1 colon, and 1 urethra. Eight patients had partially characterised antibodies. The guidelines are easy to apply and are particularly useful in possible PNS where patients had either no or partially characterised antibodies and comparatively fewer and different types of cancer compared with definite PNS. Peripheral syndromes were commonest in possible PNS, whereas central syndromes were commonest in definite PNS. Attenuated hippocampal neurogenesis in murine HIV-1 encephalitis L. Poluektova, X. Paez, V. Meyer and H.E. Gendelman University of Nebraska Medical Center, Omaha, NE, USA Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection leads to cognitive, motor, and behavioral impairments during advanced disease. The neuropathogenesis of HIV-associated dementia (HAD) is linked to inflammatory processes regulated by virus-infected and immune activated macrophages and microglia. The neuropathological features of human disease we recapitulated in severe combined immune deficient (SCID) mice by the subcortical injection of human HIV-1-infected macrophages. Using this model we studied whether neurogenesis in the dentate gyrus (DG) could be affected by HIV-1 encephalitis (HIVE). Mice were injected with infected MDM (n=13), saline (sham-operated) (n=5) or uninfected macrophages (n=12). Following the injections (day 7 and 28), the composition of the DG was examined in serial coronal brain sections by immunostaining for newborn neurons (PSA-NCAM), microglia (iba-1), and astrocytes (GFAP). Proliferation was assessed by Ki-67 expression. An increase in numbers of PSA-NCAM+ cells followed the trauma induced by sham operation. In HIVE mice a significant ( pb0.001) reduction of PSA-NCAM+ and Ki-67+ cells was observed when compared to sham-operated mice. Increased numbers of microglia and astrocytes were seen in sham-operated and HIVE mice as compared to un-manipulated control animals. In all animal groups, the DG cellular composition was restored at day 28. We conclude that neurogenesis in the DG induced following injury is blocked by activated and HIV-1-infected MP. This data provides new insights into how cognitive and behavioral impairments may occur in advanced HAD.

Modulation of the innate immune response by NMDA receptors has neuropathological consequences I. Glezer a , H. Zekki a , C. Scavone b and S. Rivest a a Laval University, Quebec, Canada; b University of Sao Paulo, Sao Paulo, BrazilThe aim of this study was to determine whether glutamate receptors modulate the innate immune response in the brain of C3H/HeN and C3H/ HeJ mice; the latter bear a loss of function in the toll-like receptor (TLR) 4 gene. Mice received an intrastriatal (IS) infusion of lipopolysaccharide (LPS), the exogenous ligand for TLR4, and were killed at several times thereafter. This treatment activated the transcription of a variety of genes involved in the control of the innate immune response. MK-801, an antagonist of NMDA glutamate receptor subtype, exacerbated the effects of the endotoxin in the brain of C3H/HeN mice but not in TLR4-deficient animals. The ipsilateral side of C3H/HeN mice exhibited stronger hybridization signals for the mRNA encoding TLR2, CD14, TNF-alpha, and IkappaB-alpha at various times after the treatment combining MK-801 and LPS. This robust inflammatory response in the brain of C3H/HeN mice was not associated with any convincing signs of neurodegeneration or demyelination that was verified via numerous approaches and at time up to 2 weeks after injection. However, animals that received long-term IS infusion of LPS, together with MK-801, exhibited a significant increase in demyelination levels within the ipsilateral side. Our results demonstrate that binding of glutamate to NMDA receptors modulates LPS-induced innate immune reaction in a TLR4-dependent manner. This acute response may be crucial to eliminate bacterial cell wall components and minimizing tissue injury. However, sustained deregulation of proinflammatory signaling involving NMDA receptors leads to demyelination and is likely to be a mechanism participating in such pathological conditions.

Analysis of damage, inflammation and proliferation/neurogenesis after oxygen glucose deprivation in organotypic hippocampal slice cultures O. Chechneva a , K. Dinkel a and K.G. Reymann a,b a Leibniz Institute for Neurobiology, Project Group Neuropharmacology, Magdeburg, Germany; b Institute for Applied Neurosciences, Magdeburg, GermanyNeurological insults such as stroke or epilepsy are associated with a defined inflammatory response whose role in damage and tissue repair is controversially discussed. The aim of this study is to elucidate how inflammation after oxygen-glucose-deprivation (OGD) affects damage and proliferation/neurogenesis in organotypic hippocampal slice cultures (OHC). We characterized the damage (PI uptake), proliferation (BrdU incorporation), neurogenesis (BrdU/Doublecortin) and the inflammatory response (microglia numbers, cytokine levels of IL-1beta, IL-6 and TNFalpha mRNA) over a timecourse (0, 2, 6, 16 and 24 h after OGD). Massive neuronal degeneration was revealed as early as 6 h after OGD in the pyramidal cell layer of the hippocampus. At the same timepoint significant increase of OX-42+ microglia cells was detected in areas CA1 and CA3. Furthermore, 6 h after OGD TNF-alpha, IL-6 and IL-1 beta mRNA upregulation was observed. In our system damage and inflammatory activation occurred before (6 h after OGD) the induction of cell proliferation (16 h after OGD) and neurogenesis (24 h after OGD). Detailed correlation analyses of our obtained data are currently being performed. First results indicate that OGD causes neuronal death and activation of microglia cells simultaneously while proliferation/neurogenesis is triggered later. Our study investigates how inflammation, neuronal damage and neurogenesis are related.

Outcomes of brain injury in aging: differential expression of cytokines and chemokines during secondary neuron death R. Sandhir, N.E.J. Berman and R.M. Klein University of Kansas Medical Center, Kansas City, KS, USA The incidence of traumatic brain injury (TBI) has a bimodal distribution with peaks in young adulthood and old age. It is generally assumed that the elderly fare worse than young individuals following TBI. Enhanced expression of proinflammatory cytokines and chemokines is linked to neuronal and glial responses to brain injury. In this study, we investigated the mRNA expression of cytokines (TNF-alpha, IL-6, IL-1-beta and IFNgamma), chemokines (MCP-1 and RANTES) and iNOS by RT-PCR in thalamus 1, 3 and 7 days after ablation of the visual cortex in old (24 months) and young (4 months). This injury axotomizes thalamic neurons, but does not directly damage neuronal cell bodies. Following injury there is enhanced gene expression for MCP-1, RANTES, IL-1beta and iNOS in thalamus in old compared to young mice. Maximal expression of all four genes is observed 24 h following injury. It appears that during aging there is an increase in the inflammatory response to injury. The increased expression of these critical molecules in inflammatory cascades may be responsible for the increased susceptibility of the aging brain to injury. Recognition of these age-specific differences may help in the development of novel therapeutic regimes for the aging population. Supported by NS38282, K-BRIN, The Lied Foundation.The pro-inflammatory cytokine interferon-gamma (IFN-gamma) has traditionally been associated with inflammatory CNS disease and more recently with ischemia-induced pathology. Using a murine model of focal cerebral ischemia, we found no evidence for induction of IFN-gamma mRNA after permanent middle cerebral artery occlusion. In addition, we found that mice deficient in IFN-gamma or IFN-gamma receptors developed neocortical infarcts similar in size to those in wild type. In contrast, MBP promoter-IFN-gamma-transgenic mice consistently developed significantly larger infarcts than non-transgenic mice. As IFN-gamma is a potent activator of microglia-macrophages, we investigated the involvement of microglialmacrophage-derived TNF in the increased infarction. Numbers of TNF mRNA-expressing microglia-macrophages and levels of TNF mRNA and TNF in IFN-gamma-transgenic and non-transgenic mice were similar. Furthermore, the ischemic brain damage in IFN-gamma-transgenic mice was unaffected by recombinant soluble TNF receptor I. Taken together, the data argues against a role for IFN-gamma in cerebral ischemia under normal conditions. However, when present IFN-gamma significantly exacerbates ischemia-induced brain damage by mechanisms that appear to be independent of TNF or synergistic neurotoxic interactions of IFN-gamma and TNF. Irrespective of the mechanism(s) involved, this enhancing effect of IFN-gamma on ischemia-induced neurotoxicity may need to be considered in diseases, where immune IFN-gamma is involved, such as multiple sclerosis. Mycophenolate mofetil: a promising immunosuppressant in multiple sclerosis L. Gogovska and R. Ljapcev Clinic of Neurology, Faculty of Medicine, Skopje, Macedonia Objective: To investigate the short-term efficacy and safety of Mycophenolate mofetil (MM) in patients with Multiple Sclerosis (MS). Method: In an open-label study, 17 MS patients received MM (CellCept) in a dose of 500 mg twice daily for 6 months. In six MS patients MM was added to Rebif (22 mcg 3Â/week, s.c.). We enrolled patients with secondary progressive MS with or without relapses, with deterioration of N1 point in Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) score during previous 6 months, and patients with relapsing-remitting MS with N2 relapses in the previous 6 months. The primary outcome measures were the change in EDSS and the proportion of patients who improved, remained stable or worsened in disability. Results: Benefit from treatment was observed in all patients included in the study. After 6 months on MM, 14 patients (82.3%) improved presented by a reduction of at least 1 point in EDSS if baseline EDSS was 4.5 or less, and change of 0.5 point if baseline EDSSN5.0. Three patients (17.6%) remained stable. This study also showed significant beneficial effect on relapse rate and on proportion of relapse-free patients. No major side effects were observed. Conclusions: MM may be a potential treatment option for patients with progressive MS. Its potential to stabilize the disease course, to reduce the relapse rate and the safe side effect profile would make MM a useful drug for MS patients who do not benefit from established therapies.

Mitoxantrone therapy in secondary progressive multiple sclerosis combination with glatiramer acetate: preliminary results B. Bastan, B.I. Cikrikci, A. Kurne, K. Karlioguz and R. Karabudak Hacettepe University, Ankara, Turkey Introduction: Following advances in the understanding of the immunological mechanisms that underlie the pathogenesis of MS, a growing arsenal of immunomodulatory agents is available in the recent years. These therapies have been shown to be reducing the relapse rate, disability progression and new magnetic resonance imaging lesions in MS. However, MS patients all, do not respond well to treatment with these drugs. Compared to a single agent, combining immunomodulators and/or immunosuppressive drugs may be another approach to improve therapeutic efficacy in well-selected subgroups. Methods: Clinically or laboratory supported definite progressive MS patients having evidence of deterioration of at least 1.0 point on the EDSS over the preceding 18 months were included in the study. Mitoxantrone has been added to their initial immunomodulatory therapy that was glatiramer acetate in our group. All were treated with this combination therapy according to the protocol. Physical, neurological examination, laboratory and MRI were performed in regular intervals. Conclusion: Our results indicate that combination therapies with mitoxantrone can be beneficial in secondary progressive, relapsing progressive subgroups and in patients having refractory response to other immunomodulatory therapies. In literature there is limited information on the combination of glatiramer acetate with mitoxantrone. This concomitant usage pointed out promising results through the tolerability and safety profiles and can be an option in non-responding progressive subgroup of MS patients. Further clinical studies will expand our view for this combination protocol.

Has leptin a role in immunoregulation of multiple sclerosis? S. Misso a , B. Feola a , A. Minerva a , G. Fratellanza a , G. Orefice b , E. Lombardi a and A. Di Lauro a a Azienda Ospedaliera S. Sebastiano, Caserta, Italy; b Università Federico II, Napoli, ItalyMultiple sclerosis (MS) is considered a T cell-dependent chronic inflammatory disease of the central nervous system. Tumor necrosis factor alpha, IL-4, IL-10 and IL-12 are key regulators of the T helper (Th1\Th2) balance, which is supposed to be involved in many pathological conditions including immune-mediated inflammatory diseases of central nervous system such as MS. In this study we explored the influence of leptin on the kinetic of sistem Th1\Th2. The expression of leptin together with a selection of proinflammatory cytokines was examined in serum and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) of multiple sclerosis patients free of therapy and in healthy donors. The serum leptin, IL-12, IL-4 and TNF alpha levels were significantly higher in MS patients. No significative difference of sVCAM, sICAM-1 and IL-10 levels was found in serum and CSF between patient and control subjects. In CSF leptin, IL-12 and TNF alpha were decreased compared with controls. These results suggest that overexpression of leptin, IL-12, IL-4 and TNF alpha in MS patients may exacerbate the inflammatory response; furthermore leptin levels appear to regulate pathogenic T-cell immune function. This study identifies the serum leptin level as a useful marker for disease activity of MS; further studies are in progress to evaluate the influence of therapy (corticosteroids, interferonbeta) on leptin levels.

Azathioprine suppressive activity on T cells: insight of a novel action mechanism A. Aldinucci a , B. Mazzanti b , T. Biagioli a , A. Parigi a , C. Ballerini a and L. Massacesi a a Department of Neurological and Psychiatrical Sciences, University of Florence, Florence, Italy; b Department of Organic Chemistry, University of Florence, Florence, Italy Azathioprine (Aza), and its active metabolite 6-mercaptopurine (6-MP), is an immunosuppressive medication that inhibits DNA synthesis. It has been demonstrated that their metabolites may induce apoptosis of T cells after CD28 costimulation. For this purpose, T cell response to recall antigens was studied in multiple sclerosis patients that underwent AZA therapy. Proliferation and cytokine production were evaluated before and during the treatment. Frequency of T cell response to recall antigens was decreased ( p=0.02). These results suggest that Aza in vivo may determine activation induced cell death. We also investigated the in vitro effects of 6-MP on T cell proliferative response to myelin basic protein (MBP) and not self influenza virus peptide (Flu-HA). 6-MP strongly suppressed proliferation both of MBP and Flu-HA specific reactive T cell clones in a dosedependent manner, indicating that the immunosuppression observed in vivo is not antigen specific. To dissect direct action of 6-MP on T cells from possible effects on antigen presentation, 6-MP pre-treated peripheral blood lymphomonocytes were used as antigen presenting cells (APC) in proliferation assays: T cell proliferation was inhibited in the same manner, suggesting that 6-MP also acts on APC function. These data indicate that Aza activity on T cell response is more selective than previously believed and may also be potentially tolerogenic. Immunomodulatory therapies and low dose Azathioprine reverse partially and significantly visual and neurologic deficits in progressive forms of multiple sclerosis D. Milder Prince of Wales Hospital, Sydney, Australia Purpose: To determine the effect of the addition of Imuran 25 or 50 mg daily to immunomodulatory therapies in patients with progressive forms of multiple sclerosis. Methods: Imuran in a dose of 25 to 50 mg daily was added to immunomodulatory therapies in the form of Glatiramer actetate, Interferon beta-1b, Interferon beta-1a (subcutaneous) and interferon beta-1a (intramuscular) in 35 patients with progressive forms of multiple sclerosis. Patients were followed for 12 to 24 months. Results: Partial and significant reversals in cognition, visual acuity, colour vision, balance, upper limb coordination, strength, sensation, micturition and fatigue were present in 25 patients. Four patients improved transiently and subsequently declined, allegedly at a lesser rate. Six patients did not improve. Primary progressive, progressive relapsing and secondary progressive cases responded similarly to the addition of Azathioprine. The effects of the four immunomodulatory therapies were unable to be distinguished. Conclusions: These observations, those of a single observer, suggest a beneficial effect, at least in the medium term, of the addition of Imuran to immunomodulatory therapies. Controlled clinical trials appear to be indicated. Video recordings are to be presented.

Direct comparison of Azathioprine and Interferon B1a efficacy on prevention of new brain lesions in relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis A. Barilaro, A. Repice, A. Parigi, R. Taiuti, G. Pellicanò and L. Massacesi University of Florence, Florence, Italy Direct comparison of the efficacy in multiple sclerosis (MS) of the immunesuppressive drug Azathioprine (Aza) and a reference therapy as Interferon beta1a (IFN) has never been carried out. In this study efficacy on new brain lesions of the two medications was compared in relapsingremitting patients (n=24) followed with brain monthly MRI for 6 months. The patients included received Aza at 2.5-3 mg/kg/day or IFN, 22 mcg 3Â/week. After 6 and 3 months, respectively, the patients were again evaluated with brain monthly MRI for 6 months and with one additional brain MRI after other 6 months. The Gd+ lesion number observed before treatment was 2.33 and 2.36/scan, respectively, in the Aza and in the IFN treated group. The Gd+ lesion number observed during treatment was 0.72 and 0.49/scan (69% and 79% reduction) respectively in the Aza and in the IFN group. The difference was not statistically significant. Equivalent differences were observed for the Gd+ lesion volumes and for the T2 new lesion number and load during the same period. During the second 6 months of evaluation, the total new lesion number was 1.7 and 2/patient, respectively, in the Aza and in the IFN group. The difference was not significant. These data indicate equivalent efficacy of the two treatments.
Mitoxantrone as rescue therapy in worsening relapsing-remitting MS patients receiving IFN-beta J. Correale, C. Rush, A. Amengual and M.T. Goicochea

We assessed the action of Mitoxantrone (MX) as rescue therapy in patients with relapsing-remitting (RR) Multiple Sclerosis (MS), whose disease activity worsened despite IFN-beta treatment. Ten very active RR MS patients treated previously with IFN-beta, who experienced frequent relapses and rapid worsening of disability, were evaluated. Patients received MX 12 mg/m 2 monthly for 3 months, and then returned to the original treatment with IFN-beta. Clinical disease activity and MRI images were studied at 3-month intervals during 6 additional months. Thereafter, patients with stabilisation of clinical and MRI parameters continued under IFN-beta treatment. Unresponsive patients then received MX 12 mg/m 2 every 3 months. Neutralizing anti-IFN-beta antibodies, and production of IL-6, IL-10, IL-12, IFN-gamma, IgG and IgM antibodies by anti-MOG peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) were evaluated at 3-month intervals. Following treatment with MX, 70% of patients were returned to IFN-beta treatment stabilising EDSS and relapse rate during 15-18 additional months follow-up. In contrast, in 30% of the patients taken off MX and returned to IFN-beta treatment, EDSS score deteriorated and the number of exacerbations increased significantly. These patients were again switched to MX treatment at 3-month intervals, stabilising EDSS and relapse rate during 15-18 additional months. Clinical findings correlated significantly with the number of Gd-enhancing lesions disclosed in MRI scan. MX treatment was associated with a significant decline in the number of IL-6, IL-12, IFNgamma, IgG and IgM anti-MOG PBMC. We conclude that MX is a safe rescue therapy for RR MS patients who experience rapid and severe worsening of their disease despite IFN-beta treatment.

back_matter.text: Multiple sclerosis: IFN-beta induces CD123+BDCA2-dendritic cells that produce IL-6 and IL-10 and have no enhanced type I interferon production in response to virus Y.M. Huang a , U. Bave b , S. Adikari a , A. Sanna c and G. Alm d a Karolinska Institute, Stockholm, Sweden; b Uppsala University, Uppsala, Sweden; c University of Sassari, Sassari, Italy; d Biomedical Center, Uppsala, Sweden IFN-beta, an approved drug for multiple sclerosis (MS), acts on dendritic cells (DC) by suppressing their production of IL-12p40 and increasing IL-10. This results in Th2-biased immune responses. The nature of IFN-betamodulated DC remains elusive. Previously, we observed that IFN-beta dose-dependently induces expression of CD123, i.e. a classical marker for plasmacytoid DC, on human blood monocyte-derived myeloid DC. Such IFN-beta-modulated DC produce predominantly IL-10 but are IL-12 deficient, with potent Th2 promotion. In the present study, we further characterize IFN-beta-modulated DC by using recently identified blood DC antigens (BDCA), and investigate their ability to produce type I IFN in response to virus stimulation. We show that IFN-beta induces development of CD123+ DC from human blood monocytes, which co-express BDCA-4 but are negative for BDCA-2, a specific marker for plasmacytoid DC. Such IFN-beta-modulated DC produce large amounts of IL-6 and IL-10, but no IL-12p40 and have no enhanced IFN-alpha and IFN-beta production after exposure to viruses. The findings indicate that IFN-beta-modulated DC represent a myeloid DC subset with diminished CD11c, BDCA-1 and CD1a expression, having potent Th2 promoting function but no enhanced ability to produce type I IFN in response to viral stimulation. Interferon beta 1-b treatment may reverse the axonal dysfunction in multiple sclerosis C. Takeuchii a , K. Ota b , Y. Shimizu a , T. Ohashi a , K. Ohara a , Y. Ono a and M. Iwata a a Tokyo Woman's Medical University, Tokyo, Japan; b Tokyo University of Science, Tokyo, Japan Background: Axonal damage is taken as the important factor of disability in multiple sclerosis (MS) and was recently considered to be a feature even in the early stage of the disease. Measurement of axonal dysfunction can be obtained using proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy by quantity signal intensity of N-acetylaspartate (NAA). Interferon beta (IFN) treatment reduces new inflammatory lesions and the frequency of relapses, and also slows the progression of disability of MS. The effect of IFN on axonal damage is not known. Method: Single voxel MRS was performed on eight MS patients with IFN beta 1-b therapy and 11 patients without therapy. Regions of interest obtained MS lesions and normal appearing white matter (NAWM). Signal intensity of NAA relative to creatinin (Cr) was measured. The Wilcoxon signed-ranks test was used to compare changes in metabolites ratio between month 0 (pre-treatment) and month 24. Results: NAA/Cr in NAWM showed a significant increase of 24% ( p=0.018) 24 months after the start of IFN therapy, however, the overall mean NAA/Cr ratio had increased 7% (not significant). There were no significant changes in untreated patients. Discussion: Disability of MS was considered to be related to axonal damage, which appeared even in NAWM. Our data may suggest that IFN therapy recovers axonal metabolism in NAWM, as a consequence of reduced demyelination. Conclusion: Axonal dysfunction in MS may be partially reversible by IFN therapy. A 42-year-old woman, treated with subcutaneous interferon-beta 1b for multiple sclerosis, developed right ulnar nerve mononeuropathy 10 days after interferon injection in the medial aspect of the arm. Nine days after the onset, electrophysiological examination revealed a near complete motor conduction block at the injection site. MRI showed ulnar nerve hyperintensity on T2-weighted images and focal gadolinium enhancement on T1weighted images with fat suppression. After a 5-day methylprednisolone course, recovery of the strength in the flexion and adduction of the hand occurred. However, 25 days after the onset distal CMAP amplitude recorded from abductor digiti minimi (ADM) was decreased and equalized CMAP from proximal stimulation. Two weeks later SAP was not recordable and fibrillation appeared in ADM and first dorsal interosseous. These data indicate a neuropathy with marked axonal loss. However, early functional conduction failure seems to have preceded wallerian degeneration, causing the initial conduction block, in fibres for hand muscles, whereas it regressed in fibres for the flexor carpi ulnaris. Necroses and other skin reactions following subcutaneous interferon injections have been ascribed to local interstitial inflammation or vasculitis. We suggest that in our patient inflammation triggered by the interferon injection into or close to the nerve could have involved nerve fibres and/or vasa nervorum causing the delayed appearance of the neuropathy.

Fcgamma receptor expression of peripheral blood leukocytes in multiple sclerosis (MS) patients treated with interferon-beta or glatiramer acetate S. Gavasso, N.K. Aarskog, K.-M. Myhr and C.A. Vedeler Neurology University Hospital, Bergen, Norway Background: IFN-beta and glatiramer acetate are used as immune modulating medications to improve the long-term course of MS. Their effects are not completely characterised, but there appears to be an immunomodulatory shift from a Th1 to a Th2 response accompanied by the production of anti-inflammatory cytokines. Fcgamma receptors are important as they combine humoral and cellular immunity, balance activation and inhibition of immune reactions and influence the pathogenesis of infectious and autoimmune diseases. We investigated the influence of immuno-modulatory medications on the expression of leukocyte Fcgamma receptors. Methods: Blood samples from 12 MS patients treated with IFN-beta (4) or glatiramer acetate (8) were collected at time intervals 0, 1, 3 and 6 months after treatment. Expression of activating FcgammaRI, FcgammaRIIA and inhibiting FcgammaRIIb were measured by real-time quantitative PCR. Results: There was a significant increase in the expression of FcgammaRI during the first 3 months after treatment with IFN-beta or glatiramer acetate. There were no differences in the expression of FcgammaRI after 6 months or of the FcgammaRIIa or FcgammaRIIb during the 6 months of treatment. Conclusions: IFN-beta and glatiramer acetate induce a temporary increase in the expression of the activating FcgammaRI on peripheral leukocytes during the first 3 months of treatment. The functional significance of these findings remains uncertain. Objective: Inflammation and immune activation appear to play a role in the pathogenesis of multiple sclerosis (MS). RANTES is a beta chemokine produced by activated T cells which in vitro influences the course of the inflammatory response. Glatiramer acetate (COP-1) is an immunomodulatory drug used in the treatment of MS. The clinical effects of COP-1 are thought to be largely mediated by a T-helper 1 to T-helper 2 shift, although its mechanisms of action remain still to be fully clarified. Aim of this study was to evaluate the effect of COP-1 on RANTES production. Induction of tolerance for alpha B-crystallin in alpha B-crystallin knock-out mice R. Verbeek, H. Van Noort and A. Plomp TNO Prevention and Health, Leiden, The NetherlandsPrevious data indicate that in humans a strong pro-inflammatory memory Tcell response exists against the CNS myelin antigen alpha B-crystallin, which qualify it as a potential autoimmune target in multiple sclerosis. In our study we were able to specifically tolerize these pro-inflammatory memory T-cells for alpha B-crystallin in an animal model. Further efforts are made towards a clinical study. Since in contrast to humans, rodents are naturally tolerant for self alpha B-crystallin, the tolerization studies were performed in alpha B-crystallin knock-out mice that are highly responsive to the protein antigen and that lack all form of naturally tolerance for alpha B-crystallin. Tolerance-inducing protocols were started 3 weeks after immunization with alpha B-crystallin in CFA. Tolerance was induced by administering intravenous alpha B-crystallin in the tail vein in various dosetiming regiments. Low dose induction of tolerance led to an almost complete abrogation of T-cell responsiveness in lymph node-derived T cells upon subsequent antigenic challenge. Although a limited induction of the T cell response was detected after in vitro re-challenge this was swiftly followed by a state of non-responsiveness. Even a boost with antigen in adjuvant after tolerance induction did not reverse the tolerant state. In contrast to the T-cell response, an increased antibody response was detected. Future efforts will be made to study the tolerance inducing mechanisms such as anergy or regulatory T-cells and the role of antibodies. Tolerance to experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis: targeting of C-type lectins J.M. Kel a , M. Luca a , J.W. Drijfhout b , F. Koning b and L. Nagelkerken a a TNO Prevention and Health, Leiden, The Netherlands; b Leiden University Medical Center, Leiden, The Netherlands Introduction: Antigen presenting cells employ C-type lectins, including mannose-receptors (MR) for efficient uptake of glycosylated proteins. Targeting of such receptors under steady state conditions can induce antigen-specific tolerance. Here we studied whether in vivo targeting of MR-positive cells can induce tolerance to EAE. Methods and results: SJL mice were immunized with a mannosylated form of the encephalitogenic peptide PLP139-151 (M-PLP139-151). Strikingly, mice immunized with M-PLP139-151 did not develop EAE and were largely resistant to subsequent EAE induction with non-mannosylated PLP139-151. Irrelevant mannosylated peptides were unable to accomplish this effect, so the process was antigen specific. Histological analysis revealed minimal infiltration of mononuclear cells in the CNS of M-PLP139-151 immunized mice. Shortly after immunization T cells from PLP139-151 and M-PLP139-151 immunized mice responded similar to re-stimulation in vitro. However, mice immunized with M-PLP139-151 have an impaired Th1 response as measured by delayed-type-sensitivity. Treatment of recipient mice with soluble M-PLP139-151 in an adoptive transfer model significantly reduced EAE symptoms, suggesting a role for local CNS APC in the diseaselimiting effect of M-PLP139-151. Conclusion: Targeting of C-type lectins can induce antigen specific tolerance to EAE by a mechanism comprising inadequate induction or reactivation of effector T cells.

Schmidt a , G. Kfllner a , T. Kerkau b , R. Gold a,c and T. Hqnig b a Department of Neurology and b Department of Virology and Immunobiology, University of Würzburg, Würzburg, Germany; c Institute for MS research, University of Göttingen and Gemeinnützige Hertie Stiftung, Göttingen, GermanyHere we focused on the therapeutic efficacy of the superagonistic anti-CD28 mAB JJ316 on monophasic and relapsing rat EAE. Effects of histamine and specific histamine-receptors agonists on a T cell line activated against a myelin peptide B. Gallo, S. Musio, S. Scabeni, R. Mantegazza and R. Pedotti C. Besta Neurological Institute, Milan Italy Histamine, a biogenic amine, is well recognized as an immunoregulatory agent in allergic and inflammatory reactions. Recently, histamine has been postulated to play an immunoregulatory role in experimental allergic encephalomyelitis, the animal model of human multiple sclerosis. To explore the role of histamine in this disease, we tested the effect of histamine and its agonists for the histamine receptor (HR) 1, 2 and 3 on a T cell line (TCL) activated against myelin proteolipid protein (PLP)-139-151. For this purpose, TCL were stimulated by the specific antigen in the presence or absence of histamine, HTMT dimaleate (a selective H1R agonist), dimaprit dihydrochloride (a selective H2R agonist), and (R)-amethylhistamine dihydrobromide (a selective H3R agonist). T cells were prepared at a concentration of 5Â10 5 and 2.5Â10 6 cells/ml of irradiated splenocytes were added to act as antigen presenting cells. Histamine or HRs specific agonists were added to cells cultures at a concentration ranging from 10 À9 to 10 À4 M. Our results suggest that the effects of histamine and, at a lower extent, of histamine specific agonists on T cells proliferation, as well as on cytokine profile, is highly variable with the different doses. However, preliminary results obtained with the specific agonists, suggest that H1R agonist reduces T cells proliferation on a dose dependent manner, and slightly increases interferon-gamma and interleukin-10 production.
